titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Kenneth Silverman Research Collection on Samuel F.B. Morse MC 173
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by University Archives staff.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-06-18T15:47-0400

did.unittitle: Kenneth Silverman Research Collection on Samuel F.B. Morse
did.physloc: This collection is stored offsite. Please contact the repository for access.
did.abstract: This collection contains research materials collected by Kenneth Silverman while working on his book Lightning Man: The Accursed Life of Samuel F.B. Morse. Materials include photocopied articles and essays, microfilm, and correspondence (mostly transcribed) dating from 1792 to 1892. This collection does not include original materials from Morse.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders in Boxes 1-3 are arranged chronologically. Box 4 is arranged alphabetically by topic. Boxes 5 and 6 are arranged by document type.
The files are grouped into four series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection includes photocopied articles and essays, microfilm, correspondence (mostly transcribed) and other research materials. The dates range from 1792-1892. The folders in the collection are arranged chronologically and by subject.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Kenneth Silverman currently serves as professor emeritus of English at New York University. He is the author of several biographies, including those of Samuel Morse, Cotton Mather, and Edgar Allen Poe. The Life and Times of Cotton Mather, perhaps his best-known work, won both the Bancroft Prize in History and a Pulitzer Prize for Biography. Silverman is also a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
Samuel F.B. Morse, noted artist and inventor, served as a professor of painting and sculpture at New York University. In 1838, he perfected his most famous invention, the telegraph.

list.item: All biographic information about Kenneth Silverman from the NYU website.
Dim, Joan Marans, and Nancy Murphy Cricco. The Miracle on Washington Square: New York University. Lanham: Lexington, 2001.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Published citations should take the following form: Identification of item, date (if known); Kenneth Silverman Research Collection on Samuel F.B. Morse; MC 173; box number; folder number; New York University Archives, New York University Libraries.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
New York University Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2641
Fax: (212) 995-4225
E-mail: university.archives@library.nyu.edu

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
Open for research without restrictions. This collection is in
off-site storage .

did.unittitle: Series II: Subject File/Index and Other Papers
Series III: Articles, Depositions, and Electronic Materials
The Papers of Samuel F.B. Morse (LC MSS 16, 372: Reels 1-35)
Samuel F.B. Morse and Other Members of the Morse and Walker Families, 1861-1869 (LC MSS 6295 A)
Jedidiah Morse Papers (N-YHS: Misc. Reel # 10--negative only)
History of Science (Early American Telegraph Companies, pamphlets, 1845-1861; Morse, S.F.B., Examination of the Telegraphic Apparatus, 1869; Morse's Patent by Kendall)
Goldsmiths' Kress Library of Economic Literature (Alfred Voil, The American Electro-Magnetic Telegraph, 1845; Description of the American Electro-Magnetic Telegraph, 1845)
